DataElement.preferredName: Central Pathology Review Post ABVD Regimen Hodgkin Lymphoma Positron Emission Tomography Confirmed Indicator Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: information related to the confirmation of Hodgkin Lymphoma, a malignant disease of the lymphatic system, following administration of a chemotherapy regimen consisting of doxorubicin hydrochloride (Adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine and dacarbazine by a centralized laboratory.:A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Central Pathology Review Post ABVD Regimen Hodgkin Lymphoma Positron Emission Tomography Confirmed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the confirmation of Hodgkin Lymphoma, a malignant disease of the lymphatic system, following administration of a chemotherapy regimen consisting of doxorubicin hydrochloride (Adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine and dacarbazine by a centralized laboratory.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The process by which specimens are sent to a central lab for confirmatory analysis using standardized methods and result criteria in order to minimize inter-reviewer differences thereby improving the accuracy of pathology data.

Concepts.definition: The process by which specimens are sent to a central lab for confirmatory analysis using standardized methods and result criteria in order to minimize inter-reviewer differences thereby improving the accuracy of pathology data.

Property.preferredName: Post ABVD Regimen Hodgkin's Lymphoma Positron Emission Tomography Confirmed
Property.preferredDefinition: Post; occuring after.:A chemotherapy regimen consisting of doxorubicin hydrochloride (Adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine and dacarbazine, used alone or in combination with radiation therapy, for the primary treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma.:A lymphoma, previously known as Hodgkin's disease, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.  There are two distinct subtypes: nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma and classical Hodgkin's lymphoma.  Hodgkin's lymphoma has a bimodal age distribution, and involves primarily lymph nodes.  Current therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma has resulted in an excellent outcome and cure for the majority of patients. -- 2003:A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:Confirmed; having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
A regimen consisting of doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine and dacarbazine that can be used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).

A lymphoma characterized by the presence of relatively few malignant cells called Reed-Sternberg cells and mononuclear Hodgkin cells that are admixed with nonneoplastic inflammatory cells. The malignant cells have a distinctive immunophenotype; they are positive for CD30 and CD15 and negative for CD3, CD20, and CD45.

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
